title: Stoeger Coach Gun
text:
The Stoeger Coach Gun is a <a href="double-barreled%20shotgun">double-barreled shotgun</a>. It is marketed and distributed by <a href="Stoeger%20Industries">Stoeger Industries</a> in <a href="Accokeek%2C%20Maryland">Accokeek, Maryland</a>. It is manufactured by E.R. Amantino (Boito) in <a href="Veran%C3%B3polis">Veranópolis, Brazil</a>.
The Coach Gun is a side-by-side shotgun. While suitable for <a href="upland%20hunting">bird hunting</a>, <a href="clay%20pigeon%20shooting">clay target shooting</a> or home defense, it is primarily designed for <a href="cowboy%20action%20shooting">cowboy action shooting</a>. As the name implies, it is a <a href="coach%20gun">coach gun</a> style shotgun, similar to those used to defend <a href="stagecoach">stagecoach</a>es in the <a href="American%20Old%20West">American Old West</a>.
Features.
The Stoeger Coach Gun has been produced in 12 <a href="gauge%20%28bore%20diameter%29">gauge</a>, 20 gauge and <a href=".410%20bore">.410 bore</a>. The <a href="chamber%20%28firearms%29">chambers</a> are three inches long, to accommodate either 2¾ inch or 3 inch <a href="shotgun%20shell">shells</a>. Barrel lengths include 18, 20 and 24 inch. The gun has a raised center rib with a brass bead front sight. The Coach Gun has dual triggers, one for each barrel. The <a href="safety%20%28firearms%29">safety</a> mechanism is located on the tang, on the upper rear part of the <a href="receiver%20%28firearms%29">receiver</a>. Opening the <a href="break-action">action</a> automatically engages the safety. To comply with cowboy action shooting regulations, the gun does not have ejectors, but it does have an extractor.
